Formato application/PDF URL del recurso [http://hdl.handle.net/11651/4764](http://hdl.handle.net/11651/4764) Idioma eng Acceso Acceso abierto Compartir Metadata [Show full item record](/handle/11651/4764?show=full) Abstract There is a concern scientists and policymakers that the COVID-19 crisis might permanently change the nature of work. We study how labor demand in Mexico has been affected during the pandemic by web scraping job ads from a leading job search website. As in the U.S., the number of vacancies in Mexico declined sharply during the lockdown (38 percent). In April there was a change in the composition of labor demand, and wages dropped across the board. By May, however, the wage distribution and the distribution of job ads by occupation returned to their pre-pandemic levels. decline in specific requirements (gender and age), no temporary increase in the average in paid for particular occupations. In sum, we find no evidence of a significant or permanent change in labor demand during the pandemic in Mexico.
